title-group.article-title: Modeling the Transition between Dense Metal and Damaged (Microporous) Metal Viscoplasticity

article-meta.aff: 1Université de Toulouse, ICA-ISAE (EA 814) – 10 avenue Edouard Belin, BP 54032, 31055 Toulouse cedex 4, France

abstract.p: This article presents a physically motivated approach, which has been developed in order to describe the transition of behavior between dense metal plasticity and microporous metal plasticity in the context of dynamic plasticity and adiabatic conditions. Considering that void germination requires a certain amount of plastic deformation, a ‘primary’ hole nucleation criterion as well as a statistical law governing the ‘secondary’ hole formation kinetics has been proposed. In a consistent way, the hole nucleation criterion accounts for the accelerating effects of stress triaxiality and the delaying effects of temperature and strain rate. In addition, a modification of the GTN model was proposed, allowing for describing cavity growth under shear loading. The 3D constitutive equations were implemented as user material in the engineering finite element computation code Abaqus®. Numerical simulations were conducted considering a single finite element under uniaxial tensile loading and simple shear then notched cylindrical samples under remote uniaxial tensile loading. The numerical results clearly show the influence of the hole nucleation criteria on the ductile damage and failure.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION: SCOPE AND AIMS
sec.p: During the process of ductile fracture, holes generally initiate in the following two ways: primary voids germinate from inclusions, whose concentration may be evaluated from metallurgical considerations (Franklin, 1969); secondary voids nucleate from second-phase particles with an expansion, which is supposed to be delayed with regards to primary void germination. Moreover, the mechanisms of formation of primary and secondary holes from particles are triple: fracture of particle–matrix interface (decohesion), failure of the particle, or microcracking of the matrix surrounding the particle (see, e.g., Hancock and Mackenzie, 1976). Cavitation at grain boundary triple point or irregularity is also observed (see, e.g. Goods and Brown, 1979). The process of void growth, and in particular the relation between the hole growth rate and the macroscopic strain rate, has been studied notably by Rice and Tracey (1969), Needleman (1972), and Dragon and Chihab (1985). In this context, the microinertial delaying effects at high strain rate have been emphasized by Wang (1997) and Molinari and Mercier (2001). Pursuing the process leading to ductile fracture, depending on microstructure, impurity concentration and distribution, the hole coalescence has been shown to result mainly from a mechanism of strain localization in the form of dilatational or shear bands (see, e.g., McClintock, 1968; Berg, 1970; Cox and Low, 1974), or by impingement of neighboring holes as a consequence of local necking (see, e.g., Brown and Embury, 1973; Thomason, 1985). The crack is then formed and, depending on the loading conditions, propagates, thus leading to the ultimate ruin.

Starting from this scenario, several authors have attempted to describe the consequences of the formation of microvoids on the bulk material behavior. These consequences are double: a progressive loss of the overall properties of the bulk material and the appearance, in addition to the isochoric plastic deformation due to dislocation glide in the matrix material, of an inelastic dilatancy due to void growth. In order to describe this second effect in the context of standard material, Berg (1970) proposed a pressure-dependent plastic potential. In particular, he assumed that a critical mean triaxial stress (hydrostatic stress) is required to activate the void expansion. In this approach, only a loading path involving a mean triaxial stress greater than this critical mean triaxial stress produces void growth and related dilatancy. It is noteworthy that the latter may (under moderate mean triaxial stress) or may not (under high mean triaxial stress) be accompanied by plastic deformation. In Berg’s approach, the state of material degradation is not explicitly described via an internal variable, but is viewed through its phenomenological consequences, that is, a loss of material resistance. Based on a micromechanical analysis, Gurson (1977) developed a plastic potential for slightly porous and perfectly plastic metals accounting explicitly for the concentration of voids and hydrostatic stress. Tvergaard and Needleman (1984) modified Gurson’s model in order to take notably into account isotropic strain hardening and strain rate effects (Becker et al., 1988). The so-called GTN (for Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman) model is widely used by the community of researchers dealing with ductile damage. Using the rate type formulation coupled with physical concepts, Perzyna (1984) developed an elliptic plastic potential taking into consideration cooperative effects of void growth, strain rate sensitivity, and heating. Finally, relying on the results of Rice and Tracey (1969), Rousselier (1987) established a plastic potential from the internal variable procedure in the context of thermodynamics of irreversible processes.

These approaches all apply to microporous metals, that is, all suppose initially the presence of microvoids, or equivalently assume mostly as concomitant voiding and plastic deformation incipience. Independently of the practical character of this assumption from the modeling viewpoint, it is clear that such a hypothesis is not supported physically, because cavity nucleation requires a certain amount of plastic deformation under moderate to low stress triaxiality – this consideration is implicitly accounted for in Berg’s approach. This is particularly true for materials which may be considered as pure, that is, containing a very low concentration of inclusions, and/or for which void nucleation results from cavitation at grain boundary. It must be noted that, though the attempts of modeling the void growth and coalescence are numerous in literature, see, e.g., Gologanu et al. (1997) and Siruguet and Leblond (2004a) for the first item and Pardoen and Hutchinson (2000, 2003) and Siruguet and Leblond (2004b) for the second one, a satisfying modeling of the transition from dense metal plasticity to microporous metal plasticity deserves still deeper investigation.

Furthermore, by construction, the plastic potentials proposed by Berg, Gurson–Tvergaard–Needleman, and Perzyna are not able to describe dilatancy and related cavity growth under shear loading, implying that, according to their approaches, shear loading solely cannot lead to fracture. An attempt of improvement proposed by Nahshon and Hutchinson (2008) concerning the GTN model has, however, to be quoted. In parallel, while the plastic potential due to Rousselier is not subject to this limitation, it is not able to uniquely describe dilatancy and further void growth under equitriaxial tensile loading.

To face up to deficiencies concerning notably the lack of a physically satisfying description of the transition from dense metal plasticity to microporous metal plasticity and the incapacity of describing void growth under shear or equitriaxial tensile loading, further research is needed.

In the present work, concerning the first point (voiding incipence with respect to plastic straining), we are indeed considering a solid material, which does not contain initially any voids, that is, which is not initially microporous. Hole nucleation under a positive or null stress triaxiality is supposed to require a certain amount of plastic deformation, as suggested by Goods and Brown (1979). In a way consistent with the present modeling approach, the magnitude of the critical plastic strain at hole nucleation depends on strain rate, temperature, and stress triaxiality. The approach is here directly applied to a mild steel for which the microvoids have been shown to appear at an advanced stage of plastic deformation, that is, in the necking zone of a cylindrical sample or in front of the macrocrack tip of a plate sample, both submitted to a remote uniaxial tensile loading. The high-purity, ferritic-pearlitic mild steel considered is employed as structural material in panels of naval structures. To ensure integrity of panels regarding extreme loading conditions including underwater explosions, the strain rate as well as the temperature effects are accounted for. This application context is thus expected to involve a large strain rate spectrum, from moderate to high strain rate levels. For the latter case, the adiabatic conditions are assumed further.

Concerning the second point, i.e. mixed mode, including void growth for low stress triaxialities under shear dominated loading, several authors recorded the predisposition of engineering metals to ductile fracture damage by void growth and subsequent failure for low triaxiality, shear-dominated loading paths. Recently, Barsoum and Faleskog (2007) have noted exposure to fracture for a class of steels under low triaxiality shearing and introduced a third stress invariant function, the Lode parameter (well known in plasticity of geomaterials) besides the classical stress triaxiality ratio. The Lode parameter effect on ductile failure has been studied further by Xue (2007, 2008) and Gao et al. (2010). The void shearing phenomenon acting through generalized damage variable thus encompassing the microstructural effects other than void volume fraction is at the core of the contribution by Xue (2008). The aforementioned attempt of improvement of the GTN model, proposed by Nahshon and Hutchinson (2008), consists in a phenomenological modification of the damage parameter rate by an additional term involving a third stress invariant function (other than the Lode one). In a way similar to that by Xue (2008), the void-related damage f is no longer connected uniquely to the plastic volume change. The apparent GTN potential form itself is not changed except for the meaning of f and the fact that it is now evolving under shearing and near-zero triaxiality loading conditions.

The present article aims at palliating the above-mentioned GTN model incapacity to describe void growth-related damage under shear and under low and small negative triaxiality in an alternative way preserving the classical meaning of f (i.e., the microporosity-related damage) and allowing for void growth under shear-dominated deformation. The modification proposed is based on the hypothesis of a kinematic mean stress mechanism, which governs a shift of the yield locus center towards negative stress triaxiality values along the increasing damage. The mechanism at stake may possibly be called ‘embrittlement’ related softening. Some features of void distortion and damage-induced softening in shear-dominated deformation may be related to void locking by particles/inclusions (if any) and generally to void–particle interaction, see e.g., Désoyer et al. (1988), Siruguet and Leblond (2004a) for micromechanical background.

The principle of the modeling approach involving nonconcomitant damage incipience with respect to plastic straining is described in the next section. Some experimental results for a ferritic-pearlitic mild steel are presented in the third section. The constitutive equations for an elastic-viscoplastic material undergoing the combined effects of the two-stage damage formation (void nucleation) mechanism, the mean stress kinematic shift related to ductile damage growth, isotropic hardening, thermal softening, are detailed in the fourth section. The complete model has been implemented as user material in the engineering finite element computation code Abaqus® and some numerical simulations have been conducted for a single representative volume element (RVE) and a laboratory sample submitted to a remote uniaxial tensile loading. The numerical results are shown in the final section.

sec.title: PRINCIPLE OF THE APPROACH
sec.p: In the present approach, based in part on the concepts suggested by Dragon and Ohji (1977) (see also Dragon (1985)), the metallic material is initially supposed to be exempt of microvoids. Subjected to a monotonic loading involving a positive or null stress triaxiality, it behaves elastic-(visco)plastically.

As soon as the condition for the germination of a given volume fraction f0 of microvoids, involving the equivalent plastic strain κ, plastic strain rate κ·, temperature T, and stress triaxiality ST is satisfied, the material behavior becomes pressure dependent. Consecutive damage accompanying plastic yielding may be described using one of the models cited in the introduction while being reset to time- and temperature-dependent context here. The cluster of nucleated microdefects, i.e., their nature, size and number, being reduced here to their concentration f0, is considered as a characteristic feature for a given material. The ‘package’ f0 is supposed to emerge instantaneously according to the criterion depicted below (Figures 1 and 2) depending on the loading path at stake. The quantity f0 represents thus a characteristic microporosity initiation bunch; its occurrence does not exclude further, secondary, delayed nucleation viewed as a hardening rate controlled, time-dependent process (see section Hole Nucleation Criterion and Kinetics Law).

Let us denote Φ0 and ΦI0 as the elastic domain of the sound (undamaged) material and the hole non-nucleation domain, respectively. For the preliminary explanation of the approach, let us tentatively suppose that the material behavior is temperature and rate independent. The initial elastic domain of the sound material is denoted as Φ0(0), i.e., for κ = 0, and the current elastic domain of the sound material is denoted as Φ0(κ), i.e., for κ > 0. In the same way, let us suppose tentatively that the hole nucleation condition is temperature and rate independent, and let us denote ΦI0(f0) as the criterion for which a volume fraction f0 of cavity spontaneously germinates – for e.g., particle/matrix decohesion. These domains are drawn in Figure 1(a). One can now consider various loading paths, as represented in Figure 1(b):
for the loading path LP1, involving a high stress triaxiality, the hole nucleation domain ΦI0(f0) is reached without cutting the initial elastic domain Φ0(0) of the sound material: the hole germination is neither preceded nor accompanied by plastic deformation,
the loading path LP2 involves a moderate stress triaxiality, and cuts the initial elastic domain Φ0(0) before encountering the hole nucleation domain ΦI0(f0): the hole germination occurs for a value of plastic deformation equal to κ2,
the loading path LP3 involves a low stress triaxiality, cuts the initial elastic domain Φ0(0) and is intercepted by the hole nucleation domain ΦI0(f0) for a large value of plastic deformation, namely κ3, with κ3>κ2.
Figure 1.
Principle of the approach. (a) Initial and current elastic domains for the sound material and hole nucleation locus. (b) Illustration of various loading paths σeq and pm represent the equivalent stress and the pressure, respectively.

According to these configurations, this approach is able to reproduce qualitatively the accelerating effects of the stress triaxiality (ST=-pm/σeq) on the hole germination. Let us now examine the influence of strain rate and temperature. As mentioned in the introduction, these two parameters have been shown to delay the hole nucleation. To reproduce this effect, the hole nucleation locus must expand with increasing strain rate and temperature, as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Principle of the approach. (a) Influence of strain rate on the hole nucleation locus. (b) Influence of temperature on the hole nucleation locus.
This article aims at proposing a multi-surface approach based model accounting for the aforementioned effects.

sec.title: PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS ON THE MATERIAL
sec.p:
The material used in the present study is a ferritic-pearlitic mild steel widely used in the automotive and railway industries as well as in shipbuilding. The chemical composition of the material is given in Table 1. According to the cementite phase diagram, the material consists of 87 wt% free (pro-eutectoide) ferrite and 13 wt% pearlite. The lamellar pearlite, embedded in the ferritic matrix, is composed of 88.34 wt% ferrite and 11.66 wt% cementite. The microstructure of the undeformed material is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Initial microstructure of the ferritic-pearlitic material used in the present study. The ferrite is represented in dark and the pearlite in light. Table 1.
Composition of the mild steel (DH36) used in the present study.

Ni (%) Cr (%) V (%) Nb (%) Ti (%) AI-T(%)

A series of mechanical tests at low and high strain rates and at various initial temperatures were carried out in order to identify the mechanisms of deformation and damage of the material. With this aim in view, various specimen geometries were used, including smooth and notched, cylindrical and plane ones, see Figure 4 and also Tables 2 and 3. The notched cylindrical specimens were dimensioned using Bridgman formula (Bridgman, 1952), while the notched plane specimens were dimensioned via numerical simulations. Stress triaxiality values indicated in this section correspond to the initial, maximum stress triaxiality values, i.e., at the center of the cross section. The cross section area value is the same for each type of quasi-static notched specimens, i.e., 28.27 mm2 for the cylindrical ones and 20 mm2 for the plane ones. Figure 4.

sec.title: Thermomechanical Characterization
sec.p: Quasi-static tests were performed using a conventional hydraulic machine in a strain rate range comprising between 10−4 s−1 and 10−2 s−1 for the tensile tests on smooth specimens and in a strain rate range comprising between 10−3 s−1 and 10−1 s−1 for the compressive tests. In order to quantify as accurately as possible the strain rate effects, some strain rate jump tests were also carried out. The same procedure was followed for the study of the influence of temperature, where temperature jump tests were realized at low strain rate. Some dynamic, compressive, and tensile tests, performed using a split Hopkinson pressure bar (SHPB), allowed for determining the effects of high strain rate on the material behavior. Compressive dynamic tests were carried out at 450 s−1 and 3500 s−1, and tensile dynamic tests at 1500 s−1.

Experimental stress–strain curves obtained at low and high strain rate and at room temperature are shown in Figure 5(a). For reason of confidentiality, the y-axis values are not given here. The fluctuations of the material response at a high strain rate are experimental artifacts. The genuine response may be obtained by adequately filtering the experimental results. Tensile stress–strain curves were cut before necking. According to Figure 5(a), one can note the presence of a Piobert–Lüders plateau on quasi-static tensile stress–strain curves, as the consequence of the solute atom diffusion-induced dislocation anchorage. This effect is known to be less significant for compressive loading. Figure 5(a) clearly shows the nonlinear hardening of the material with an asserted tendency to saturation observed from compressive tests. The strain rate effect seems to be moderate at low strain rates and becomes significant at high strain rates, as it is frequently observed for mild steels. Moreover, an asymmetry can be observed between the yield stresses obtained from compressive and tensile tests (see, in particular, the curves at high strain rates in Figure 5(a)). Figure 5(b) shows the experimental stress–strain curves obtained at low strain rates and at various initial temperatures. The softening effect of the initial temperature is significant in the range varying between 20 °C and 190 °C. This thermal softening does not seem to affect material hardening. Figure 5.
Experimental results on smooth specimens. (a) Strain rate effects in tension and compression T0 = 20°C. (b) Temperature effects in compression. Monotonic and temperature jump tests κ· = 10−3s−1.

The experimental curves obtained from quasi-static tensile tests carried out at room temperature and at 5 mm/min on smooth and notched, cylindrical, and plane specimens are shown in Figure 6. To be compared with each other, the curves are given in the engineering axial stress – defined as the ratio of the axial load over the cross section area – versus displacement. One can observe from both Figure 6(a) and (b) that the higher the stress triaxiality the higher the engineering axial stress and the smaller the displacement at fracture, as expected. On the other hand, the Piobert–Lüders plateau disappears when the stress triaxiality becomes high. Figure 6.
Experimental results on smooth and notched specimens. (a) Cylindrical specimens; (b) Plane specimens.

Some experimental curves corresponding to tensile tests on smooth and notched, cylindrical, and plane specimens with close stress triaxiality values are superposed in Figure 7(a). The maximum engineering axial stress versus stress triaxiality is shown in Figure 7(b). Figure 7(a) and (b) show very similar results for cylindrical and plane specimens. According to Figure 7(b) the dependence of the maximum engineering axial stress on the initial stress triaxiality value seems to be affine in the range of the study. Figure 7.
Superposition of experimental results on smooth and notched, cylindrical, and plane specimens. (a) Engineering axial stress vs. displacement; (b) Maximum engineering axial stress vs. stress triaxiality.

sec.title: Fracture Investigation
sec.p:
Some tensile tests were interrupted during the deformation process before fracture and post-mortem samples were observed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM). The presence of microdefects, namely microvoids and microcracks, was only observed at an advanced stage of the deformation process, that is, in the necking zone of a cylindrical sample (Figure 8), or in front and in the close neighborhood of the mesocrack tip of notched plane samples (Figure 9). According to Figure 8, the microhole nucleation seems to proceed from cavitation at grain boundary triple point or irregularity, and the microcrack initiation by decohesion at the boundary separating the two phases namely ferrite and pearlite. Figure 8.
Evidence of (a) microvoids and (b) microcracks at grain boundary and ferrite-pearlite interphase (SEM) in the necking zone of a cylindrical sample. Figure 9.
Mechanism of crack propagation in notched plane specimens under tensile loading.

Figure 9 shows the presence of macrocracks, which initiated from the center of the sample and propagated towards the edges, in the opening mode (Mode I) in the specimen width, see front view (on the left) of Figure 9, and in the shearing mode (Mode II) in the specimen thickness, see side view (on the right) of Figure 9. The lips of the macrocracks are indented, as expected in the case of ductile fracture. Upstream from the macrocracks, one can observe mesocracks, whose tortuous trajectory may be macroscopically viewed as straight. Microdefects, whose concentration is very low, are localized in front of the mesocracks or in the very close neighborhood of the meso/macrocracks.

Due to the quasi-spherical geometry of the holes (Figure 8(a)), the related damage may be considered as isotropic and a scalar internal variable may be used to describe the corresponding state of material deterioration. This is not the case for the microcracks, which are strongly oriented, as shown in Figure 8(b). Related damage should thus be considered as anisotropic and described via, e.g., a second-order (at least) tensorial internal variable (see, e.g., Dragon, 1985; Chow and Wang, 1988). However, we are here assuming that the microcracking-induced damage is diffuse so that we consider it as statistically isotropic in a first approximation. Discriminating the respective effects of microvoids and microcracks could be done in a prospective enriched version of the model presented below. In the following, damage will tentatively refer to both cavity growth and microcracking and will be described via a single internal variable, namely the volume fraction (porosity f) of both quasi-spherical cavities and crack-like voids.

sec.title: CONSTITUTIVE EQUATIONS
sec.p: Such a scenario implies a transition between conventional dense metal plasticity and microporous metal plasticity and the definition of conditions for the microvoid induced damage initiation. The case of the mild steel briefly described in the third section is taken as reference material.

sec.title: Kinematical Preliminaries
sec.p: Let denote as C0 and Ct the initial and current configurations of a continuum body. The second-order tensor allowing to express the deformation gradient between these two configurations is called F¯¯. We are here considering an intermediate configuration Cinter obtained by elastic unloading with respect to the current configuration Ct. Such a concept implies the decomposition of the deformation gradient F¯¯ as the product F¯¯=V¯¯eQ¯¯F¯¯p, where V¯¯e represents the pure ‘elastic’ stretching (F¯¯e=V¯¯eR¯¯e, R¯¯e being the orthogonal elastic rotation tensor), Q¯¯ the rotation of the material frame (with regards to the laboratory frame), and F¯¯p the inelastic deformation gradient (Lee, 1969). This further allows for the following Eulerian kinematic decompositions (Lubarda, 1994): (1)d¯¯=[F·¯¯F¯¯-1]S=d¯¯e+d¯¯p;ω¯¯=[F·¯¯F¯¯-1]AS=W¯¯+ω¯¯e+ω¯¯p where d¯¯ is the total rate of strain tensor and ω¯¯ the spin tensor. The symbols d¯¯e and ω¯¯e represent, respectively, the elastic rate of strain and spin, W¯¯=Q·¯¯Q¯¯T represents the rotation rate of the material frame, and d¯¯p and ω¯¯p, respectively, represent the inelastic rate of strain and spin. The objective rotational derivative a¯¯∇ of a second order tensor a¯¯ is given by: (2)a¯¯∇=a·¯¯-W¯¯a¯¯+a¯¯W¯¯
Note that the time derivative of the rotated tensor a¯¯Q, defined by a¯¯Q=Q¯¯Ta¯¯ Q¯¯, is expressed as: (3)a·¯¯Q=Q¯¯T(a·¯¯-W¯¯a¯¯+a¯¯W¯¯)Q¯¯=Q¯¯Ta¯¯∇Q¯¯

Assuming small elastic deformation, i.e., F¯¯e=V¯¯e=δ¯¯+e¯¯ with e¯¯:e¯¯<<1, moderate plastic strain and isotropic hardening, the rotation rate W¯¯ may be simplified from (12) as follows (Schieck and Stumpf, 1995): (4)W¯¯=ω¯¯=[F·¯¯F¯¯-1]AS

With (4), the rotational derivative (2) represents the Zaremba-Jaumann derivative. The rotation rate W¯¯ may also be defined from the polar decomposition of the deformation gradient F¯¯=R¯¯U¯¯=V¯¯R¯¯ as: (5)W¯¯=R·¯¯R¯¯T

With (5), the rotational derivative (2) represents the Green-Naghdi derivative (Green and Naghdi, 1965). Moreover, the tensor ɛ¯¯e represents here a spatial elastic strain measure, namely, ɛ¯¯e=lnV¯¯e. Under the aforementioned assumption of small elastic strain, the following expression is obtained: (6)d¯¯e=ɛ¯¯e∇

sec.title: Plastic Potential of the Sound Material
sec.p: The internal variable procedure has been followed to model the material behavior. The instantaneous state of the material is described via the Helmholtz free energy Ψ(T;ɛ¯¯e,κ), whose arguments are the absolute temperature T, the elastic strain tensor ɛ¯¯e and the isotropic strain hardening variable (or equivalent plastic strain) κ. The Helmholtz free energy is decomposed into a recoverable part Ψr(T;ɛ¯¯e), a purely thermal part ΨT(T) and a stored part Ψs(T;κ): (7)Ψ(T;ɛ¯¯e,κ)=Ψr(T;ɛ¯¯e)+ΨT(T)+Ψs(T;κ)

The various parts of Ψ(T;ɛ¯¯e,κ) in (7) are given in the forms: (8){ρΨr(T;ɛ¯¯e)=λ2(Trɛ¯¯e)2+μɛ¯¯e:ɛ¯¯e-αTKTrɛ¯¯eΔTρΨT(T)=-ρC2T0ΔT2ρΨs(T;κ)=h(κ)g(T) where λ and µ represent Lamé elastic coefficients, K is the bulk modulus (K=λ+2μ/3). The quantities αT, ρ, and C represent the thermal dilatation coefficient, the mass density and the specific heat, respectively. In (83), h(κ) represents the stored energy of cold work and g(T) the thermal softening function. The set of thermodynamic forces connected to the state variables is given by: (9){σ¯¯=ρ∂Ψ∂ɛ¯¯e=ρ∂Ψr∂ɛ¯¯e=(λTrɛ¯¯e-αTKΔT)δ¯¯+2μɛ¯¯eρs=-ρ∂Ψ∂T=-(ρ∂Ψr∂T+ρ∂ΨT∂T+ρ∂Ψr∂T)=αTKTrɛ¯¯e+ρCT0ΔT-h(κ)g'(T)r=ρ∂Ψ∂κ=ρ∂Ψr∂κ=h'(κ)g(T) where σ¯¯ represents the Cauchy stress second-order tensor, s entropy and r isotropic hardening force. In the following, we are considering the decomposition σ¯¯=-pmδ¯¯+(2/3)σeqn¯¯, with pm the pressure, pm=-Trσ¯¯/3, δ¯¯ the second-order identity tensor, σeq the equivalent stress, σeq=(3/2)s¯¯:s¯¯, s¯¯ being the deviatoric part of the Cauchy stress tensor (Trs¯¯=0), and n¯¯ the direction of the isochoric plastic yielding, n¯¯=(3/2)s¯¯/σeq.

According to (1), (6), (7)–(9) and the Clausius–Duhem inequality (Second Principle of Thermodynamics), the intrinsic dissipation Dsm for the sound material is expressed by: (10)Dsm=σ¯¯:d¯¯-ρ(Ψ·+sT·)=σ¯¯:d¯¯p-rκ·≥0
The viscoplastic yielding of the material under consideration is supposed to be well described by the plastic potential (11)Φ0=σ~eq 2-1=0;σ~eq=σeqσ¯y
The yield stress σ¯y in (11) includes a rate independent contribution σy and a strain rate induced overstress σvp: (12)σ¯y=σy+σvp

Based on the experimental campaign summarized in the third section, the rate independent contribution σy in (12) incorporates the combined effects of strain hardening, via a Voce type law, and thermal softening, via a power law: (13)σy=[R0+h'(κ)]g(T);h'(κ)=R∞[1-exp(-kκ)]β;g(T)=1-(TTmelt)m where (R0,R∞,k,β) are isotropic hardening related constants and (Tmelt,m) thermal softening related constants, with Tmelt the melting point. With (13), the rate independent contribution σy in (12) and the isotropic hardening force r in (83) take thus the form (14)

The common way of reproducing tensile/compressive asymmetry in a constitutive model consists in taking into account the third invariant of the stress tensor (see, e.g., Cazacu and Barlat, 2004). This effect of the loading path may be alternatively considered as a thermally activated mechanism involving the mean stress, as was done by Graff et al. (2004). This approach has been retained in the present work, leading to the following expression of the strain rate induced overstress σvp in (12): (15)σvp=Y[κ·exp(VapmkBT)]1/n where (Y,n) are viscosity-related constants and (Va,kB) behavior asymmetry-related constants, with Va = Vh β3 where Vh is a constant and β Burgers vector magnitude (β = 2.5 Å), and with kB Boltzmann constant (kB = 1.3804 × 10−23J/K).

The sound material satisfies the conditions of standard materials in the irreversible thermodynamics sense. Applying the normality rule yields: (16)d¯¯p=Λ∂Φ0∂σ¯¯=ɛ·0 pDn¯¯;ɛ·0 pD=Λ∂Φ0∂σeq=2Λσ~e'qσ¯y;κ·=23d¯¯p:d¯¯p=ɛ·0 pD;Λ≥0

Where Λ represents the viscoplastic multiplier. Finally, heating during any adiabatic processes is supposed to proceed predominantly from dissipation Dsm in (10) (see Longere and Dragon (2009) for further details), yielding (17)ρCT·=Dsm=(σeq-r)κ·≥0

The identification of the model constants was performed using the gradient-based optimization method (see, e.g., Cailletaud and Pilvin, 1993; Andrade-Campos et al., 2007). For reason of confidentiality, the values are not given in this article. The superposition of experimental and numerical results is shown in Figure 10, indicating satisfying agreement – the brutal drop in stress for the test at 3500 s-1 is due to the catastrophic failure of the sample and must not be considered. Figure 10.
Experimental and numerical results (a) in compression and (b) in tension.
Note: Some temperature jump tests were carried out in compression at low strain rate; one of them is shown in (a).

sec.title: Plastic Potential of the Damaged Material
sec.p: As for the sound material, the Helmholtz free energy Ψ is assumed to describe the instantaneous state of the damaged material. The volume fraction of defects f is added to the set of arguments of Ψ. Let us consider the following general decomposition of Ψ: (18)Ψ(T;ɛ¯¯e,κ,f)=Ψr(T;ɛ¯¯e,f)+ΨT(T,f)+Ψs(T;κ,f)+Ψf(f,…)

The introduction of f in each contribution to the state potential Ψ, namely the recoverable, the purely thermal and the stored ones, indicate that the presence of defects may affect elastic, thermal and plastic properties. The last term Ψf(f,…) in (18) accounts for potential damage related energy. The set of conjugate forces becomes: (19){σ¯¯=ρ∂Ψ∂ɛ¯¯e=ρ∂Ψr∂ɛ¯¯eρs=-ρ∂Ψ∂T=-(ρ∂Ψr∂T+ρ∂ΨT∂T+ρ∂Ψs∂T)r=ρ∂Ψ∂κ=ρ∂Ψs∂κF=-ρ∂Ψ∂f=-(ρ∂Ψr∂f+ρ∂ΨT∂f+ρ∂Ψs∂f+ρ∂Ψf∂f)

It can be noted that, according to (194), there are several contributions to the energy release rate (with respect to the damage variable f) F. Moreover, depending on the form given to (18), F may have a nonzero value even in absence of damage. For the damaged material, the intrinsic dissipation Ddm thus becomes (20)Ddm=σ¯¯:d¯¯-ρ(Ψ·+sT·)=σ¯¯:d¯¯p-rκ·+Ff·≥0

According to (20), there are now two contributions to the intrinsic dissipation Ddm of the damaged material: one due to isochoric plasticity, namely Dp, and the other one due to void growth induced damage, namely Dd: (21)Ddm=Dp+Dd≥0;Dp=σeqɛ·pD-rκ·;Dd=-pmɛ·pM+Ff· where the distortional and dilatational quantities ɛ·pD and ɛ·pM proceed from the decomposition d¯¯p=ɛ·pDn¯¯+(1/3)ɛ·pMδ¯¯.

At this stage of the development, considering slightly porous metals, we are assuming a weak damage-plasticity state coupling and strong damage-plasticity kinetic couplings, according to the terminology of Lemaitre and Marquis (1989). In other words, we are assuming that the state potential (7)-(8) and the forces (9) still hold during the damage process considered herein. We are indeed focusing our attention on the damage-plasticity coupling intervening at the level of the yielding conditions, as it is mostly done when modeling microporous metal behavior (see, e.g., Gurson, 1977); it must be noted that accounting for damage-plasticity state coupling does not imply significant changes in the present methodology. The intrinsic dissipation in (20) thus reduces to: (22)Ddm=Dp+Dd≥0;Dp=σeqɛ·pD-rκ·;Dd=-pmɛ·pM

As mentioned before, plasticity dissipates energy in the form of heating. In addition, we are here assuming that void growth generates a temperature rise at the void wall. In this sense, void growth also dissipates energy in the form of heating. The quantities σeqɛ·pD-rκ· and -pmɛ·pM are thus sources of heat.

In parallel, as mentioned in the introduction, some current models of microporous metal are deficient when they have to describe inelastic dilatation under shear loading. This is particularly the case for Berg, Gurson-GTN, and Perzyna models, probably because in these models some physical phenomena are not accounted for. It is known that viscoplastic deformation may cause brittle-like damage in metals, as observed notably in creep where microvoids and microcracks initiate along the grain boundaries. At an advanced stage of deformation, a material may thus contain defects potentially at the origin of brittle fracture (in the sense mentioned above) and defects potentially at the origin of ductile fracture (in the current sense). In such a material, there are thus two sources of damage induced softening, the latter being described via the aforementioned microporous plasticity oriented models. We are here describing the consequences of the former by introducing an embrittlement-related softening mechanism, acting as a kinematic stress drop causing a shift of the yield locus center towards negative stress triaxiality values. It must be noted that this phenomenon has yet been suggested by Dragon and Ohji (1977). A like shift may also result from void/inclusion interaction, see the micromechanical analysis by Siruguet and Leblond (2004a).

While the asymmetry of the sound material behavior was assumed to result from a thermally activated mechanism and to vanish when the strain rate tends to zero, see (15), it is postulated here that the asymmetry of the damaged material behavior is dependent predominantly on the porosity and vanishes when the porosity tends to unity – the material behaves progressively as a porous one – i.e., pr(f)→0 as f → 1. This property of the kinematic mean stress moreover permits preserving the yielding conditions under pure pressure for moderate to high porosity. The principle is shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Shift of the microporous potential with the porosity-dependent kinematic mean stress.

As an application of the present approach, a modified version of the GTN model is proposed. Consider thus the following modified GTN potential: (23)ΦG=σ~e'q 2+2q1fcosh[-32q2(p~m+p~r)]-(1+q3f2)=0;p~m=pmσ¯y;p~r=prσ¯y where (q1, q2, q3) are material constants. In a first approximation, in agreement with the dependence of the mean stress under equitriaxial stress on porosity for GTN model, the dependence of the kinematic mean stress, or equivalently of the kinematic pressure as used here, is logarithmic: (24)pr=bln(q1f) with b a positive constant value.

After Berg (1970), the normality rule applies to the damaged material: (25)d¯¯p=Λ∂ΦG∂¯¯σ=Λ(∂ΦG∂σeqn¯¯-13∂ΦG∂pmδ¯¯)=ɛ·G pDn¯¯+13ɛ·G pMδ¯¯ where the distortional and dilatational parts, namely ɛ·G pD and ɛ·G pM, respectively, of the inelastic strain rate d¯¯p are given by (26)ɛ·G pD=Λ∂ΦG∂σeq=2Λσ~e'qσ¯y;ɛ·G pM=-Λ∂ΦG∂pm=3q1q2fΛsinh[-32q2(p~m+p~r)]σ¯y
The evolution law of the isotropic hardening variable κ is deduced from the equality of the macroscopic plastic work rate with the microscopic one (Gurson, 1977): (27)κ·=σeqɛ·G pD-pmɛ·G pM(1-f)σ¯y
According to the aforementioned considerations, adiabatic heating is evaluated from (28)ρCT·=σeqɛ·G pD-rκ·-pmɛ·G pM

The porosity rate f· is decomposed into a contribution due to growth of existing defects and a contribution due to the formation of new defects, see (291). The former, namely f·g, is deduced from the classical hypothesis of matrix incompressibility, see (292), whereas the latter, namely f·n, is the subject of the following sub section: (29)f·=f·g+f·n;f·g=(1-f)Trd¯¯p=(1-f)ɛ·G pM;fg(0)=f0

sec.title: Hole Nucleation Criterion and Kinetics Law
sec.p: The hole nucleation criterion describes the conditions for which a specific volume fraction of ‘primary’ voids f0 instantaneously germinates. A ‘secondary’ void initiation kinetic law is also proposed.

sec.title: ‘Primary’ Hole Nucleation Criterion
sec.p: To ensure the instantaneous transition between dense metal plasticity and microporous metal plasticity, the hole nucleation criterion and the microporous metal potential must possibly have the similar aspect and corresponding expressions. As the GTN model is assumed as the plastic potential in this paper, see (23), the hole nucleation criterion ΦI0 is proposed in a close form: (30)

As this criterion involves the yield stress σy and the pressure pm together, hole nucleation is clearly controlled by the stress triaxiality. Now, in order to describe the delaying effects of the strain rate (see, e.g., Regazzoni and Montheillet, 1985) and the temperature (see, e.g., Brown and Embury, 1973), in the hole nucleation process, the critical stress σc must increase with increasing strain rate κ· and temperature T. In a first approximation, the dependence of the critical stress σc on the strain rate κ· and on the temperature T is postulated in a form close to (12). The critical stress σc is thus tentatively postulated in the simple form: (31)σc=σI+σvp;σI=α(R0+R∞)

The condition 0 < α < 1 obviously favors the convergence of the dense metal potential with the microporous metal potential – the lower and upper bounds of α may be better adjusted by accounting for temperature and strain rate effects.

The expression of the equivalent plastic strain at ‘primary’ hole nucleation κ0=κ(f0) may be explicitly deduced from (13) and (30) as: (32)κ0=-1kln(1-{σcR∞[1-(TTfusion)m]-1[(1+q3f0 2)-2q1f0cosh(-32q2(pm+prσc))]1/2-R0R∞}1/β)

The plastic strain at ‘primary’ hole nucleation κ0 in (32) is shown in Figure 12 as a function of the stress triaxiality for various values of temperature, strain rate, and coefficient α, see (32). The graphs in Figure 12 show clearly that the hole nucleation criterion given in (30) is able to reproduce, at least qualitatively, the accelerating effects of stress triaxiality and the delaying effects of temperature (Figure 12(a) and strain rate (Figure 12(b). The influence of the ratio α in (31) is shown in Figure 12(c), where it can be clearly seen that a large value of α delays ‘primary’ holes germination. Figure 12.
Influence of (a) temperature, (b) strain rate, and (c) α on the plastic strain at hole nucleation. Here, the stress triaxiality is defined by -pm/σ¯y.

sec.title: ‘Secondary’ Hole Formation Kinetics Law
sec.p:
In the present approach, the formation of ‘secondary’ voids, in addition to the ‘primary’ voids whose germination is controlled by the above criterion, is postulated. These ‘secondary’ voids include microvoids of the same nature of the ‘primary’ voids but nucleating later, as well as nano-voids germinating between macrovoids and being consequently at the origin of the coalescence by localized shearing. In agreement with this definition, the ‘secondary’ void nucleation kinetics is supposed to be controlled by the rate of hardening, see (331). This hypothesis is consistent with the fact that hole germination requires a certain amount of plastic deformation. Based on the works by Molinari and Wright (2005), the kinetic law for secondary nucleation is assumed to be well described by a Weibull type distribution function, see (332): (33)f·n=B〈σ·y〉;B=fsuppσc〈ΦI0〉p-1exp(-ΦI0 p);fn(0)=0 where p is a constant (p = 2, as suggested by Molinari and Wright (2005)) and where fsup represents the upper bound of the nucleated ‘secondary’ void volume fraction. 〈.〉 represents McCaulay brackets. As shown in Figure 13, the ‘secondary’ hole nucleation rate is zero at hole germination, then it increases until reaching a maximum and finally decreases to zero. Figure 13.
Evolution of the distribution function B with 〈ΦI0〉.

sec.title: NUMERICAL SIMULATIONS AND CONFRONTATION WITH EXPERIMENTS
sec.p: The model detailed in the previous section was implemented as user material (Vumat) in the engineering finite element computation code Abaqus®. The integration algorithm is briefly described in the following and some numerical simulations employing Abaqus® were conducted considering a cube under tension and shear as well as structures under tension.

sec.title: Numerical Procedure
sec.p: The numerical integration is conducted in the Green-Naghdi rotating frame (considering f.ex. ɛ·¯¯Q=Q¯¯Td¯¯Q¯¯ and σ·¯¯Q=Q¯¯Tσ¯¯∇Q¯¯, see the kinematical preliminaries at the beginning of the fourth section and (3) in particular) using the classical return mapping procedure combined with the Newton–Raphson solving algorithm (see Aravas (1987) and Vadillo et al. (2008) for further details). Note that the construction of a Vumat in Abaqus® for simulations using explicit time integration scheme does not need any tangent operator.
Dividing (262) by (261), or inversely, allows for eliminating the viscoplastic multiplier Λ and defining Ξ as (34)Ξ=ɛ·G pD∂ΦG∂pm+ɛ·G pM∂ΦG∂σeq=0
From the incremental viewpoint, (34) may be rewritten as (35)ΞΔ=ΔɛG pD∂ΦG∂pm+ΔɛG pM∂ΦG∂σeq=0
The numerical integration consists thus in solving the following system of equations
– For the dense material (36){Φ0(σe'q;Hα)=0σeq=σeq e-3μΔɛG pDΔH=h(ΔɛG pD,σeq,H)

– For the microporous material (37){ΦG(σeq,pm;Hα)=0ΞΔ(σeq,pm;Hα)=0pm=pm e+KΔɛG pMσeq=σeq e-3μΔɛG pDΔH=h(ΔɛG pD,ΔɛG pM,σeq,pm,H) where σeq e and pm e represent the trial, equivalent stress and pressure respectively, and ΔH the system of complementary laws (16)–(17) and (27)–(29) written in the incremental form. The constants K and µ represent the bulk and shear moduli respectively. The thermal dilatation is supposed to be negligible in the present approach. Adiabatic conditions are furthermore assumed to be valid for plastic equivalent strain rate κ· greater than 1s−1. In addition, failure is supposed to occur as soon as the porosity reaches the critical value fr, leading numerically to the erosion of the concerned finite element.

sec.title: Case of a Cube Under Uniaxial Tension
sec.p:
The model was applied in the context of the numerical simulation of the tension of a representative volume element (RVE). With this aim in view, a single solid finite element was considered, with reduced integration, i.e., C3D8R. The four nodes of its lower face were constrained in the 2-direction while the four nodes of the opposite face were moved at a constant velocity of 2 m/s (leading to a plastic equivalent strain rate slightly greater to 1 s−1) during 1 s in the 2-direction. Two additional loading velocity conditions were applied, 0.2 and 20 m/s. Such a numerical procedure using a single finite element avoids structural effects. The time integration scheme was explicit. The model constants are reported in Table 4. The numerical results are drawn in Figures 14–18 in the form of stress–strain curves for a nondamageable material ETVP (ETVP stands for elastic thermoviscoplastic) and for damageable materials (ETVP-GTN), with various values of the ratio α (Figure 14), various values of f0 (Figure 15), various values of fsup (Figure 16), various values of velocity conditions (Figure 17), and various values of the initial temperature T0 (Figure 18). The dotted lines indicate the strain for which the ‘primary’ hole nucleation criterion is verified. Figure 14.
Influence of the ratio α. Tensile test on a cube. (a) Axial stress vs. axial strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. axial strain. Figure 15.
Influence of f0. Tensile test on a cube. (a) Axial stress vs. axial strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. axial strain. Figure 16.
Influence of fsup. Tensile test on a cube. (a) Axial stress vs. axial strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. axial strain. Figure 17.
Influence of strain rate. Tensile test on a cube. (a) Axial stress vs. axial strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. axial strain. Figure 18.
Influence of initial temperature. Tensile test on a cube. (a) Axial stress vs. axial strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. axial strain. Table 4.
Microporous model related constants for the numerical simulation of a cube under tension.
q1 q2 q3 f0 α b (MPa) fsup fr
1 1 1 10−3 0.65 115 0.16 1

It is worthy of recall that the ratio α influences (quasi) directly the yield stress and the strain for which ‘primary’ holes germinate. This fact is particularly visible in Figure 14, where holes germinate for an axial strain value close to 0.03 with α = 0.45 and close to 0.17 with α = 0.65 (also see Figures 14(b) and Figure 12(c)). As it can be deduced from (332), Figure 14(b) also shows that a low value of α tends to increase the ‘secondary’ holes nucleation rate.

Let us recall that f0 is the volume fraction of ‘primary’ holes which instantaneously nucleate as soon as the criterion (30) is satisfied. According to Figure 15(a), a large value of f0 leads to early instability (softening). In addition, the instantaneous appearance of holes in the material provokes a sudden drop in its resistance. The magnitude of the drop in resistance is coherently more important for large value of f0. On the contrary, a low value of f0 will preserve some continuity of stress between the dense state and the microporous state of the material. Moreover, one can note that for a porosity value of 0.1 the material can no more be considered as microporous, but as porous. A more physical porosity value at hole nucleation is typically comprised between 10−4 and 10−3.
The upper bound fsup plays a role in the ‘secondary’ voids kinetic rate, see (332). For this reason, as it can be seen in Figure 16(b), a large value of fsup yields a large value of current porosity.

One consideration which guided the definition of the ‘primary’ hole nucleation criterion was to describe the delaying effect of the strain rate. According to Figure 17(a) (see dotted lines) showing that for a low strain rate the hole nucleation occurs earlier than for a high strain rate, this objective has been reached, at least qualitatively. The growth of the holes is also affected by strain rate, as it can be seen in Figure 17(b).

Finally, the delaying effect of temperature is clearly visible in Figure 18. One can thus conclude that the respective definitions of the ‘primary’ holes nucleation criterion and of the ‘secondary’ holes nucleation rate are able to reproduce experimental observations, at least qualitatively.

sec.title: Case of a Cube Under Simple Shear
sec.p:
We are now considering a RVE submitted to a simple shearing in order to verify the ability of the model of the fourth section to describe the consequences on the material behavior of cavity growth under shear loading. From the numerical viewpoint, the RVE is once more represented by a single finite element C3D8R. The upper side is submitted to a tangential displacement at a constant velocity of 2.3 m/s (leading to a plastic equivalent strain rate slightly greater than 1 s−1) while the lower side is constrained. The set of material constants is reported in Table 5. Shear stress-shear strain and porosity-shear strain curves are shown in Figure 19 for various values b entering the expression of the kinematic pressure softening pr, see (24). Figure 19.
Influence of kinematic pressure. Simple shear on a cube. (a) Shear stress vs. shear strain. (b) Volume fraction of holes vs. shear strain. Table 5.
Microporous model related constants for the numerical simulation of a cube under simple shear.
q1 q2 q3 f0 α b (MPa) fsup fr
1 1 1 10−3 0.65 – 0.16 1

The graphs in Figure 19(a) show the combined softening effects of adiabatic heating and cavity growth induced damage on the material behavior – for the ETVP model adiabatic heating is solely responsible for the softening behavior at large deformation. Furthermore, it is clearly visible that the loss of shear resistance of the material is more significant for large values of b. As shown in Figure 19(b) this softening effect is induced by cavity nucleation and growth. Cavity growth under shear loading has been made possible thanks to the introduction of the kinematic pressure softening mechanism governed by pr in the GTN model, see (24).

sec.title: Case of Notched Cylindrical Samples under Tension: Simulation Versus Experiment
sec.p: This section deals with the tension of notched cylindrical specimens. The configurations with a notch radius value of 1.2 mm (ST = 1.15) and 6.2 mm (ST = 0.55) (see Tables 2 and 3 and Figure 4) are considered here. Quasi-static tests were performed at room temperature and at 5 mm/min on these samples.

Concerning numerical simulations, the spatial discretization consisted in meshing one-eighth of the samples using solid finite elements with reduced integration C3D8R, as shown in Figure 20. The vertical translation of the lower face nodes is constrained while a vertical velocity is imposed to the upper face nodes. The sample material behavior is described via the model detailed in the fourth section and implemented as user material (Vumat) in Abaqus®. The material constant values are reported in Table 6. The time integration scheme is explicit. Figure 20.
Meshing of the notched cylindrical samples. (a) ST = 0.55, (b) ST = 1.15. Table 6.
Microporous model related constants for the numerical simulation of notched samples under tension.
q1 q2 q3 f0 α b (MPa) fsup fr
1 1 1 10−3 – 115 – –

Experimental and numerical results are superposed in Figures 21–23 in the form of axial load–displacement curves. These curves allow for studying the influence of various model constants on the onset of void growth induced damage and subsequent drop in load, namely that of the ratio α (Figure 21), that of the porosity upper bound fsup (Figure 22), and that of the failure porosity fr (Figure 23). Figure 21.
Comparison model-experiment. Influence of the ratio α. Tensile test on notched cylindrical samples; α = / − fsup = 0.03 − fr = 0.2. (a) ST=1.15, (b) ST=0.55. Figure 22.
Comparison model experiment. Influence of the upper bound fsup. Tensile test on cylindrical round samples; α = 0.75 − fsup = / − fr = 0.2. (a) ST=1.15, (b) ST=0.55. Figure 23.
Comparison model experiment. Influence of the failure porosity fr. Tensile test on notched cylindrical samples; α = 0.75 − fsup = 0.03 − fr = /. (a) ST=1.15, (b) ST=0.55.

Figure 21 clearly shows the effect of the critical stress σc via the ratio α, see (30), on the overall response of the notched round sample. Acting on the ‘primary’ void germination occurrence and on the ‘secondary’ void nucleation rate, see (31) and (332), the ratio α is consequently a key parameter in the model detailed in the fourth section. For early damage conditions, the ratio α value must be low, and for late damage conditions, the ratio α value must be large. Note that a large value of α provokes a progressive drop in load, contrarily to the brutal drop in load observed for a low value of α. In a same way, Figure 22 shows that increasing fsup, which accelerates the germination of ‘secondary’ voids, leads to a premature overall fracture of the sample. Finally, a large value of fr yields delaying and softening the drop in stress, as expected.
According to Figure 23, the set α = 0.75, fsup = 0.03, fr = 0.2 may be considered as satisfying for the material at stake.

As mentioned above, the drop in load observed on numerical curves in Figures 21–23 is attributed to advanced damage and ‘crack’ propagation, the latter being numerically represented by finite element erosion effect. When simulations are conducted in such a softening regime, the question of the independence of the numerical results on the size and orientation of meshing must be considered. Note that because this is not the subject of this article, an extensive study of these numerical effects has not been carried out here for the model at stake. However, comments are put forward below on this matter.

When simulating numerically the ductile fracture, two successive phenomena have to be considered generally: the localization of deformation in dilatational or shear bands leading to void coalescence, and the formation and propagation of cracks resulting from this void coalescence. The former generates a weak discontinuity, i.e., of the velocity gradient, while preserving cohesion of the material, whereas the latter provokes a strong discontinuity, i.e., that of the velocity itself, by creating free surfaces. These two mechanisms are known to be sources of pathological mesh size dependence of the numerical results during finite element analysis.

The introduction of characteristic lengths in constitutive models has been shown to favor regularization in the post-localization stage (weak discontinuity). This characteristic length, which may be related to material microstructure, is implicit in rate dependent models and in models with delay effect, see e.g., Suffis et al. (2003), or may be explicitly introduced in differential (gradient-enhanced) or integral (weighted average) nonlocal approaches, see e.g., Peerlings et al. (2001) and the works cited in this reference.

In an alternative way, the somewhat pragmatic approach developed by Longère et al. (2003, 2009) can be quoted, embedding the localization band (namely adiabatic shear band) in the representative volume element (RVE) and giving to the band the status of an anisotropic deterioration-like entity with kinematic and material consequences. The regularizing effects are favored by combining viscoplasticity and viscous deterioration and the effect of controlled deterioration rate. This method consisting in enriching the model to account for the presence of the band inside the RVE finds in a certain manner its equivalent in the method consisting in including enhanced modes in the weak discontinuity-embedded finite element formulation, as done by e.g. Huespe et al. (2009). In the sense that both methods imply the use of finite elements with a size larger than the band width and the control of the post-localization process (its onset conditions are determined using an analysis of instability or bifurcation respectively), they constitute clearly an advance regarding the approaches recommending mesh refinement to reach numerical convergence. In a same way, the numerical treatment of strong discontinuity formation and propagation, such as ductile cracking, succeeding the localization induced weak discontinuity evoked above, seems to yield better results when conducted with enriched finite elements, including cohesive model and/or extended finite element formulations, see e.g., Moës and Belytschko (2001) and Oliver et al. (2006). It must be noted that Huespe et al. (2009) propose a technique permitting the transition between weak and strong discontinuity approaches. By adopting a void coalescence criterion, as proposed by, e.g., Pardoen and Hutchinson (2000, 2003), and incorporating adequate ingredients, enabling notably to describe the kinematics of cracking, the approach developed by Longère et al. (2005, 2009) should also be suitable to describe the successive effects of both types of discontinuity.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: An elastic/viscoplastic model involving two-stage void nucleation mechanism and void growth related hardening/softening effects has been put forward for a class of structural steels subjected to rapid loading conditions.

A phenomenological modeling approach has been developed, based on some salient physical effects regarding void growth versus plastic straining, to describe the transition behavior between dense metal plasticity and microporous metal plasticity. Considering that void germination requires a certain amount of plastic deformation, a ‘primary’ hole nucleation criterion has been proposed, as well as a statistical law governing the ‘secondary’ hole kinetics. In a consistent way, the hole nucleation criterion accounts for the accelerating effects of stress triaxiality and, conversely, the delaying effects of temperature and strain rate. In this work, a modification of the GTN model has also been proposed, overcoming its inability to predict damage growth and fracture for zero and low triaxiality, shear-dominated deformations. In this respect the kinematic mean stress related shift mechanism has been introduced and quantified in the expression of the GTN plastic potential, enabling thus the damage growth under shear and under small negative triaxialities. The 3D constitutive equations have been implemented as user material in the engineering finite element computation code Abaqus®. Numerical simulations have been conducted considering a single finite element under uniaxial tensile loading and simple shear on one hand and a notched cylindrical sample under remote uniaxial tensile loading on the other hand. The numerical results show clearly the influence of the hole nucleation criterion related constants on the damage and further failure of the material.

While relying on physical observations, this work made some simplifications to focus on the problem of describing the process of late ductile damage formation. For example, despite the presence of (strongly oriented) microcracks in addition to (quasi spherical) microvoids, only the isotropic growth effects of both types of defects were accounted for. A more advanced model must involve the anisotropic consequences of the initiation and evolution of these microcracks, as done by e.g., Longère et al. (2003, 2009) in the context of adiabatic shear band induced deterioration. Moreover, it is noteworthy that the present approach may be easily completed by a coalescence criterion, as e.g. in the form proposed by Pardoen and Hutchinson (2000, 2003) and applied by Besson (2009), and extended further for describing the ductile–brittle transition.

fn.p: Figures 1, 2, 5–7 and 10–23 appear in color online: ijd.sagepub.com
